sen.j: 伊勢 貞興
sen.e: Sadaoki ISE
Sadaoki ISE
Sadaoki ISE

sen.j: 室町時代後期の人物。
sen.e: A man who lived in the late Muromachi period.
A man who lived in the late Muromachi period.
A man who lived in the late Muromachi period.

sen.j: 一説には北条早雲（北条早雲）の兄とされる人物。
sen.e: A man some suggest was an elder brother of Soun HOJO.
It is suggest he was an elder brother of Soun HOJO.
It is suggested he was an elder brother of Soun HOJO.
sen.cmt: It is suggest→It is suggestedに修正

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)後期から安土桃山時代の人物。
sen.e: A man who lived in over the late Sengoku Period and Muromachi Era and Azuchi Momoyama Period.
He lived from the late Sengoku Period to the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
He lived from the late Sengoku period (Period of Warring States) to the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
sen.cmt: 戦国時代→統一リストに基づき修正

sen.j: 本項で詳述する。
sen.e: This section describes this man.
This section provides a brief description.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity - not a literal translation but gets the meaning across
sen.e: This section provides a brief description.

sen.j: 伊勢 貞興（いせ さだおき、永禄2年（1559年）－天正10年6月13日 (旧暦)（1582年7月2日））は戦国時代 (日本)の武将・有職故実の研究家。
sen.e: Sadaoki ISE (1559 - June 13 (old lunar calendar)) was a busho (Japanese military commander) in the Sengoku Period and a researcher of Yusoku kojitsu (court and samurai rules of ceremony and etiquette).

Sadaoki ISE (1559 - June 13, 1582 [lunar calendar]) was a busho (Japanese military commander) in the Sengoku Period and a researcher of Yusoku Kojitsu (court and samurai rules of ceremony and etiquette).
Sadaoki ISE (1559 - July 12, 1582) was a busho (Japanese military commander) in the Sengoku period and a researcher of Yusoku Kojitsu (court and samurai rules of ceremony and etiquette).
sen.cmt: ユリウス→グレゴリオ暦に修正、the Sengoku periodとしました。

sen.j: 幼名は熊千代。
sen.e: His childhood name was Kumachiyo.
His childhood name was Kumachiyo.
His childhood name was Kumachiyo.

sen.j: 通称は与三郎。
sen.e: His common name was Yosaburo
His common name was Yosaburo.
His common name was Yosaburo.

sen.j: 伊勢守。
sen.e: Ise no kami (Governor of Ise Province)
He was Kami (Governor) of Ise Province.
He was the Governor of Ise Province.
sen.cmt: Kami (Governor) of Ise Province→the Governor of Ise Provinceとしました。

sen.j: 祖父は伊勢貞孝。
sen.e: His grandfather was Sadataka ISE.
His grandfather was Sadataka ISE.
His grandfather was Sadataka ISE.

sen.j: 父は伊勢貞良。
sen.e: His father was Sadayoshi ISE.
His father was Sadayoshi ISE.
His father was Sadayoshi ISE.

sen.j: 兄弟に伊勢貞為、阿古御局（異説あり）。
sen.e: His brothers are Sadatame ISE and Okogo no Tsubone (Some say incorrect.)
His siblings were Sadatame ISE and OKOGO no Tsubone (though some disagree)
sen.cmt: TenseCapital lettersRevised for clarity - although the Japanese has "兄弟", I think 阿古御局 was probably female.
sen.e: His siblings were Sadatame ISE and Okogo no Tsubone (though some disagree).
sen.cmt: OKOGO no Tsubone→Okogo no Tsuboneとし、ピリオド追加

sen.j: 旧幕臣衆。
sen.e: Former retainer of shogun
He was a former retainer of shogun
He was a former retainer of shogun.

sen.j: 伊勢流の有職故実の探究者。
sen.e: An Ise school researcher of Yusoku kojitsu
He was a researcher of the Ise school of Yusoku kojitsu.
He was a researcher of the Ise school of Yusoku kojitsu.

sen.j: 武家故実の書として「伊勢貞興返答書」を記述した。
sen.e: He wrote "Ise Sadaoki Hentosho," a book that describes Buke-kojitsu (Regulations governing the customs of the buke class)
He wrote "Ise Sadaoki Hentosho," a book that describes Buke Kojitsu (Regulations governing the customs of the warrior class).
He wrote 'Ise Sadaoki Hentosho,' a book that describes Buke Kojitsu (Regulations governing the customs of the warrior class).
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更

tit.cmt: 統一リストの表記に修正

sen.j: 伊勢氏は元は室町幕府の政所執事を務めた家柄であるが、祖父の貞孝と父の貞良が永禄6年（1563年）に三好氏との抗争に敗れ戦死して以来、衰退・没落していた。
sen.e: The Ise clan, which was originally a family line that served as Mandokoro Shitsuji (chief of Mandokoro, the Adiministrative Board) of Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), had fallen and ruined since his grand father Sadataka and his father Sadayoshi were beaten and died in the conflict with the Miyoshi clan (1563).

The Ise clan had originally served as Mandokoro Shitsuji (chief of the Mandokoro, the Administrative Board) of the Muromachi Shogunate, but had gone into decline after his grandfather, Sadataka, and his father, Sadayoshi, were defeated and killed in 1563 in conflict with the Miyoshi Clan (1563).

The Ise clan had originally served as Mandokoro Shitsuji (chief of the Mandokoro, the Administrative Board) of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), but had gone into decline after his grandfather, Sadataka, and his father, Sadayoshi, were defeated and killed in 1563 in conflict with the Miyoshi clan.
sen.cmt: the Muromachi Shogunate→the Muromachi bakufuに修正、初出のため補足追加、重複するため文末の(1563)削除、Clanの頭文字を小文字に変更

sen.j: 貞為・貞興兄弟は幕府の近習の一人にすぎなかった。
sen.e: Sadatame and Sadaoki brothers were only kinju (attendants) of the bakufu.
Sadaoki and his brother, Sadatame, did not advance beyond kinju (attendants) of the shogunate.
Sadaoki and his brother, Sadatame, did not advance beyond kinju (attendants) of the bakufu.

sen.j: 兄が病身であったために貞興が家督を継いだ。
sen.e: He succeeded as the head of the family because elder brother was feeble.
He succeeded as the head of the family because his elder brother was sickly.
He succeeded as the head of the family because his elder brother was sickly.

sen.j: 最後の将軍足利義昭が織田信長により京より追放され、室町幕府が事実上滅亡すると、貞興は明智光秀に仕えた。
sen.e: When the last Shogun of the Muromachi bakufu, Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA was banished from Kyoto by Nobunaga ODA destrucing the Muromachi bakufu in effect, Sadaoki served Mitsuhide AKECHI.
When the last shogun of the Muromachi Shogunate, Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, was banished from Kyoto by Nobunaga ODA, effectively detroying the shogunate, Sadaoki served Mitsuhide AKECHI.
When the last shogun of the Muromachi bakufu, Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, was banished from Kyoto by Nobunaga ODA, effectively detroying the shogunate, Sadaoki served Mitsuhide AKECHI.
sen.cmt: the Muromachi Shogunate→the Muromachi bakufuに修正

sen.j: 若いが智勇に優れ、行政能力だけではなく、武家故実に優れるなど軍事にも精通していたために、明智光秀の信任を得た。
sen.e: He won the confidence of Mitsuhide AKECHI for his wisdom and courage, high administrative abilities, high knowledge in military affiars and Buke-kojitsu.
He won the confidence of Mitsuhide AKECHI because, despite his youth, he had wisdom and courage, high administrative abilities, and was well-versed in military affairs and Buke-kojitsu.
He won the confidence of Mitsuhide AKECHI because, despite his youth, he had wisdom and courage, high administrative abilities, and was well-versed in military affairs and Buke-kojitsu.

sen.j: 一説には明智光秀の娘婿となったとされている。
sen.e: Some suggest that he married a daughter of Mitsuhide AKECHI.
Some suggest that he married a daughter of Mitsuhide AKECHI.
Some suggest that he married a daughter of Mitsuhide AKECHI.

sen.j: 明智光秀の配下として丹波国攻略やその他の戦役に活躍し、若いが明智家中では斎藤利三と並ぶ戦巧者として名を馳せた。
sen.e: He played an active role in wars such as a conflict with Tamba Province under Mitsuhide AKECHI and won a fame as a young yet distinguished warrior that compared Toshimitsu SAITO.

Under Mitsuhide AKECHI, he played an active role in campaigns such as the capture of Tamba Province and won fame within the Akechi family as a young yet distinguished warrior, comparable to Toshimitsu SAITO.

Under Mitsuhide AKECHI, he played an active role in campaigns such as the capture of Tanba Province and won fame within the Akechi family as a young yet distinguished warrior, comparable to Toshimitsu SAITO.

sen.j: 天正10年6月2日 (旧暦)（1582年6月21日）の明朝、明智光秀は織田信長を本能寺に攻めた（所謂、本能寺の変）の際、伊勢貞興は麾下の二千の兵を率いて織田信長の長男、織田信忠を二条城に攻め、自ら槍を振るって奮戦した。
sen.e: Early in the morning of June 21, 1582, when Mitsuhide AKECHI. raided Nobunaga ODA on Honno-ji Temple (in so-called the Honnoji Incident), Sadaoki ISE led 2000-strong force under Ishinari's command attached Nobunaga ODA's first son, Nobutada ODA on the Nijo Castle and fought desperately by wielding a spear.

Early in the morning of June 21, 1582, when Mitsuhide AKECHI raided Nobunaga ODA on Honno-ji Temple (in the so-called Honno-ji Incident), Sadaoki ISE led a 2000-strong force in attacking Nobunaga ODA's eldest son, Nobutada ODA, at Nijo Castle and he himself fought hard, wielding his spear.

Early in the morning of July 1, 1582, when Mitsuhide AKECHI raided Nobunaga ODA on Honno-ji Temple (in the so-called Honno-ji Incident), Sadaoki ISE led a 2000-strong force in attacking Nobunaga ODA's eldest son, Nobutada ODA, at Nijo-jo Castle and he himself fought hard, wielding his spear.
sen.cmt: ユリウス→グレゴリオ暦に修正、Nijo-jo Castleとしました。

sen.j: 天正10年6月13日（1582年7月2日）の昼ごろから始まった山崎の戦いでは、明智光秀軍と織田信長の弔い合戦を挑む織田信孝（豊臣秀吉・丹羽長秀など）の軍勢が山崎の地でにらみ合いが始まり、ついに日が傾き始めたころ、合戦が始まった。
sen.e: In the Battle of Yamasaki that started around the noon on July 2, 1582, a staring contest started between the forces of Mitsuhide AKECHI and the forces of Nobutaka ODA (including Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Nagahide NIWA), which challenged a battle to avenge Nobunaga ODA, and the fights at last started when the sun were about to set down.

In the Battle of Yamasaki that started around noon on July 2, 1582, a staring contest started between the forces of Mitsuhide AKECHI and the forces of Nobutaka ODA (including Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Nagahide NIWA), who were looking to avenge Nobunaga ODA, with fighting finally starting as the sun was beginning to go down.

In the Battle of Yamasaki that started around noon on July 12, 1582, a staring contest started between the forces of Mitsuhide AKECHI and the forces of Nobutaka ODA (including Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Nagahide NIWA), who were looking to avenge Nobunaga ODA, with fighting finally starting as the sun was beginning to go down.
sen.cmt: ユリウス→グレゴリオ暦に修正

sen.j: 神戸信孝軍の中川清秀隊3500余に伊勢貞興隊2000余が攻撃を開始したのが最初の激突であった。
sen.e: It was the first crash that the 2000-strong force of Sadaoki ISE started to attack the 3500-strong company of Kiyohide NAKAGAWA under the force of Nobutaka KANBE.
The opening action saw the 2000-strong force of Sadaoki ISE start to attack Kiyohide NAKAGAWA's 3500-strong company from the army of Nobutaka KANBE.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity - don't know if it needs clarifying that Nobutaka Kanbe and Nobutaka Oda were the same person
sen.e: The opening action saw the 2000-strong force of Sadaoki ISE start to attack Kiyohide NAKAGAWA's 3500-strong company from the army of Nobutaka KANBE.

sen.j: 精強な伊勢貞興隊は兵数に勝る中川清秀隊を直押しに押した。
sen.e: The powerful force of Sadaoki ISE ahrd and hard the force of Kiyohide NAKAGAWA superior in numerical strength.
Sadaoki ISE's powerful forces steadily pushed back Kiyohide NAKAGAWA's numerically superior forces.
Sadaoki ISE's powerful forces steadily pushed back Kiyohide NAKAGAWA's numerically superior forces.

sen.j: 形勢不利と見た神戸信孝軍の高山右近隊などが中川清秀隊を救援しようとした。
sen.e: The company of Ukon TAKAYAMA under the force of Nobutaka KANBE saw an disadvantageous situation and tried to help the force of Kiyohide NAKAGAWA.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Ukon TAKAYAMA's troops from Nobutaka KANBE's army saw the disadvantageous situation and tried to help Kiyohide NAKAGAWA's forces.
Ukon TAKAYAMA's troops from Nobutaka KANBE's army saw the disadvantageous situation and tried to help Kiyohide NAKAGAWA's forces.

sen.j: これを明智光秀方の斎藤利三隊が横槍を入れたために両軍入り乱れての乱戦となった。
sen.e: Then the company of Toshimitsu SAITO under Mitsuhide AKECHI interrupted the relief, resulting in a confused battle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Then Toshimitsu SAITO's company from Mitsuhide AKECHI's army interrupted the relief, resulting in a confused battle.
Then Toshimitsu SAITO's company from Mitsuhide AKECHI's army interrupted the relief, resulting in a confused battle.

sen.j: しかし、総兵力四万の神戸信孝軍と総兵力一万五千の明智光秀軍という兵力の格差が戦闘開始から1時間半を過ぎるころから顕著となった。
sen.e: One and a half hours after the battle, a difference in military strength became clearer; the 40000-strong force of Nobutaka KANBE vs. the 15000 -strong force of Mitsuhide AKECHI.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: One and a half hours after the start of the battle, the difference in strength between the 40000-strong army of Nobutaka KANBE and the 15000-strong army of Mitsuhide AKECHI was clear and
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity, accuracyArticlePunctuation - rejoined to cell F44
sen.e: One and a half hours after the start of the battle, the difference in strength between the 40000-strong army of Nobutaka KANBE and the 15000-strong army of Mitsuhide AKECHI was clear.
sen.cmt: ピリオドで終わるよう修正

sen.j: 明智光秀軍は3000余の死傷者を出して戦線離脱。
sen.e: The force of Mitsuhide AKECHI retreated from the front leaving over 3000 deaths and casualities.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Mitsuhide AKECHI's forces retreated from the front, leaving over 3000 dead and injured.
sen.cmt: Revised to rejoin to cell F43
sen.e: Mitsuhide AKECHI's forces retreated from the front, leaving over 3000 dead and injured.

sen.j: 神戸信孝軍も4000余の死傷者を出して追撃の余力はなく山崎の戦いは終わった。
sen.e: The force of Nobutaka KANBE having about 4000 deaths and casualties did not have energy any more to follow the retreated enemy, putting an end to the Battle of Yamazaki.
Nobutaka KANBE's forces, with about 4000 dead and wounded, did not have any energy left to follow the retreating enemy, putting an end to the Battle of Yamazaki.
Nobutaka KANBE's forces, with about 4000 dead and wounded, did not have any energy left to follow the retreating enemy, putting an end to the Battle of Yamazaki.

sen.j: その乱戦の中で、伊勢貞興は明智光秀の敗走を助けるために残軍を率いて殿軍を引き受けた。
sen.e: In such a confused battle, Sadaoki ISE led remaining solders to serve as the rear guard to help Mitsuhide AKECHI flee.
In the confusion, Sadaoki ISE led the remaining solders as the rear guard to help Mitsuhide AKECHI flee.
sen.cmt: Revised start of sentence for clarity
sen.e: In the confusion, Sadaoki ISE led the remaining solders as the rear guard to help Mitsuhide AKECHI flee.

sen.j: 自らも槍を振るい、奮戦したが、命運尽き24歳の人生を閉じた。
sen.e: He himself fought desperately by wielding a spear but died at the age of 24.
He himself fought desperately with his spear but died at the age of 24.
He himself fought desperately with his spear but died at the age of 24.

sen.j: 伊勢氏は兄の貞為の子孫がつづき、江戸時代には旗本となっている。
sen.e: Descendants of his elder brother Sadatame succeeded the Ise clan and became Hatamoto (direct retainer of the shogun) in the Edo Period.
Descendants of his elder brother, Sadatame, took over as heads of the Ise clan and became hatamoto (direct retainers of the shogun) in the Edo Period.
Descendants of his elder brother, Sadatame, took over as heads of the Ise clan and became hatamoto (direct retainers of the shogun) in the Edo period.
